newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: PRESS DIGEST - Pakistani newspapers - May 28.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Pakistani newspapers - May 28.

text.p: These are the leading stories in the Pakistani press on Wednesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
DAWN
- The National Bank of Pakistan and Dubai Islamic Bank have signed a $100 million memorandum of understanding to compliment each other in Islamic banking operations.

- Hafiz Pasha, Deputy Chairman of the Planning Commission, has said Pakistan plans to bring down the 1997/98 (July-June) fiscal deficit to 5.0 percent of the gross domestic product (GDP) and the current account deficit to five percent of the GDP.
- Landon Thomas, fund manager of Morgan Stanley Asset Management said each time he visited Pakistan, he found the stock market was cheaper and pessimism was deeper.
- Habib Bank president Shaukat Tarin has estimated that 25 to 35 percent workforce and some 40 percent of the branches of state-run banks was surplus.
- The government has agreed to pay 18 million rupees to 60 families of the victims of extra-judicial killings in Karachi.
- Pakistan would not cancel the agreements with private power generation plants concluded by the previous government.
BUSINESS RECORDER

- The 1997/98 budget is being envisaged with a revenue collection target of 325 billion rupees, with new taxation measures of 10 billion, debt-servicing of 275 billion with total budget outlay of 630 billion rupees.
- Insurance companies in Karachi are now reluctant to insure cars due to frequent car snatching cases.
- The National Commission on Agriculture has projected that fertiliser consumption in Pakistan will grow by six percent per annum during 1998-2000.
FINANCIAL POST
- The Sindh provincial government has leased out 8,000 acres of land in Lakhra coalfields to Smith Association Power Company of America for 30 years.
THE NEWS
- Supreme Court of Pakitan granted bail to former chairman capital development authority Shafi Sehwani.
THE NATION
- The Federal Accountability Cell has gathered substantial evidence of corruption and malpractices against former prime minister Benazir Bhutto and her spouse Asif Ali Zardari.
- An Indian military aircraft violated Pakistani airspace at very high altitude and crossed sound barrier.
- National Assembly debated the performance of power utility companies WAPDA and KESC.
THE MUSLIM
- Rangers will stay in Karachi, Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif told a delegation of MQM.
-- Islamabad newsroom 274757
